intro: Orchis intacta, commonly known as the purple marsh orchid, is a flowering plant native to wetland and marsh environments in Europe. It belongs to the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and showy, violet-blue flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are arranged in a spike and are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. Orchis intacta is an indicator species for nutrient-poor wetlands and is often found in association with other orchid species.
